story:
Elijah needs an Accessible Wheelchair Van

Elijah is a 8 year old boy who is diagnosed with quadriplegic cerebral palsy. He was born at 24 weeks gestation weighing only 1lb. 8oz. He has dystonia, spasticity dependence for walking or crawling and contractures of the muscles of the legs. He is at high risk for falls or fractures. Elijah requires the use of a wheelchair with special seating modifications, and he uses a walker that is specially designed to support his body weight and that functions like and is shaped much like a wheelchair.

Elijah needs a special adapted wheelchair van with a lift in order to transport his walker and wheelchair to and from school, numerous doctor’s appointments, community events such as church, family gatherings and school activities and therapy appointments (OT, PT, Aquatic and Hippo) that all work together to allow him to grow new skills; however, these appointments are continuous throughout the week.

As Elijah continues to grow physically, so does the challenges that I his mom is faced with. His growing body becomes more difficult to lift and transfer, and his spasticity grows stronger to overcome. These factors not only complicate the functional transfers that I perform daily, but they also increase the risk of injury to Elijah himself and to his caregivers. I transfer him on a daily basis at home and for school. He is transferred countless times a week to and from his chair and in and out of the car to attend physical therapy, occupational therapy, aquatic therapy, hippotherapy, and medical appointments. Without adaptive equipment to ease the transfers, we will face the possibility of physically wearing themselves out. Elijah will continue to require physical assistance from his parents with functional transfers therefore caregiver wellness is a top priority. Limiting the amount of physical strain will not only relieve the caregivers but it will also greatly serve Elijah as he participates in school and community activities.

Elijah is an exceptional individual with a Great Spirit and wonderful potential.  He is one that is determined to succeed in whatever he tries to accomplish.  He doesn’t give up as he has the motivation that will take him far in his life.  He has a great sense of humor and lets no challenges block his way.  As with his determination and motivation I’m not going to give up either so with all your help we should be able to raise the funding needed to get Elijah a wheelchair accessible van that he deserves.  

Thank you all for taking the time to read! We need your help in making this gift to Elijah a reality.  We can do it!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $49,195 for a accessible wheelchair van.  I'll be working with Koons Mobility Center of Annapolis, MD.  We have decided on a 2010 Honda Odyssey with modifications that will suite Elijah’s needs. We are applying for grants and I know we will receive a grant of at least $10,000 through the DDA Funding to go towards the van and we’re hoping and praying that they will approve even more up to $30,000 for a total of 40,000. So as of right now we are asking for your help in raising $5800.

What we can give you in return:

$10 dollars will get you heartfelt thanks and a shout-out on my Facebook page.

 $25 dollars will get you heartfelt thanks, a shout-out on my Facebook page, and a signed Thank you Card from family.

 $75 dollars will get you heartfelt thanks, a shout-out on my Facebook page, a signed Thank You card from family, one of Elijah's Handprint Keychain saying “Thanks for your helping hand”

 $125 dollars will get you all the above and a Unique Gift Cake from Unique Gift Cakes N' More by GiGi

 If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll put the money in savings, until we reach our goal.

The Impact

Elijah's a busy guy.  He has lots of doctors' appointments, therapy appointments, and generally loves to be out in his community.  Your gift will make a huge impact on Elijah's life, allowing him to fully enjoy all that is around him. And it will also help mom out too! Your contribution makes a difference!

Other Ways You Can Help

We get it.  We realize that not everyone can contribute financially. Here's how you can help:

  • Talk up the cause.  Post the link to our site on your Facebook, Twitter, or other social media sites.
  • Some great folk are going to be doing some benefits for Elijah over the summer.  Come out and support!
  • Say a prayer for us that God may help to press upon the hearts of those who can give financially to have the will to do so.

 

ALL Help is appreciated and please know that we will definitely PAY IT FORWARD!

Thanks so much.  If we pull this off, it will be a result of caring people who stretch themselves when times are challenging.  We love you and pray that God blesses you in many ways for reading, supporting or even considering helping us out.

Thanks for being a blessing as it’s always a blessing for someone else.

The Palmer Family

Elijah will continue to require physical assistance from his parents with functional transfers therefore caregiver wellness is a top priority. Limiting the amount of physical strain will not only relieve the caregivers but it will also greatly serve Elijah as he participates in school and community activities.
Elijah is an exceptional individual with a Great Spirit and wonderful potential.  He is one that is determined to succeed in whatever he tries to accomplish.  He doesn’t give up as he has the motivation that will take him far in his life.  He has a great sense of humor and lets no challenges block his way.  As with his determination and motivation I’m not going to give up either so with all your help we should be able to raise the funding needed to get Elijah a wheelchair accessible van that he deserves.  
Thank you all for taking the time to read! We need your help in making this gift to Elijah a reality.  We can do it!


What We Need & What You Get
We need $49,195 for a accessible wheelchair van.  I'll be working with Koons Mobility Center of Annapolis, MD.  We have decided on a 2010 Honda Odyssey with modifications that will suite Elijah’s needs. We are applying for grants and I know we will receive a grant of at least $10,000 through the DDA Funding to go towards the van and we’re hoping and praying that they will approve even more up to $30,000 for a total of 40,000. So as of right now we are asking for your help in raising $5800.
What we can give you in return:
$10 dollars will get you heartfelt thanks and a shout-out on my Facebook page.
 $25 dollars will get you heartfelt thanks, a shout-out on my Facebook page, and a signed Thank you Card from family.
 $75 dollars will get you heartfelt thanks, a shout-out on my Facebook page, a signed Thank You card from family, one of Elijah's Handprint Keychain saying “Thanks for your helping hand”
 $125 dollars will get you all the above and a Unique Gift Cake from Unique Gift Cakes N' More by GiGi
 If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll put the money in savings, until we reach our goal.


The Impact
Elijah's a busy guy.  He has lots of doctors' appointments, therapy appointments, and generally loves to be out in his community.  Your gift will make a huge impact on Elijah's life, allowing him to fully enjoy all that is around him. And it will also help mom out too! Your contribution makes a difference!


Other Ways You Can Help
We get it.  We realize that not everyone can contribute financially. Here's how you can help:

Talk up the cause.  Post the link to our site on your Facebook, Twitter, or other social media sites.
Some great folk are going to be doing some benefits for Elijah over the summer.  Come out and support!


Say a prayer for us that God may help to press upon the hearts of those who can give financially to have the will to do so.

 
ALL Help is appreciated and please know that we will definitely PAY IT FORWARD!
Thanks so much.  If we pull this off, it will be a result of caring people who stretch themselves when times are challenging.  We love you and pray that God blesses you in many ways for reading, supporting or even considering helping us out.
Thanks for being a blessing as it’s always a blessing for someone else.
The Palmer Family

story:
Who I am

I am an award-winning travel writer who is currently based in Indonesia, finishing up a two-year volunteer assignment as a fundraising advisor for a maternal and child health center.

What I Need

I have been invited to participate as a panelist in the NonFictionNow conference in Melbourne, Australia in November 2012. I need to cover my airfare ($500), four days hotel accommodation ($600) and the reduced registration fee for panelists ($200).  That's it. i'll cover my incidental costs and meals.

I may still be able to attend if I can cover my airfare and registration fee. I can try throwing myself on the mercy of another writer and beg to share their hotel room. Or try sleeping in Melbourne's parks. The grass is soft and the air is warm at that time of year, and the parks are pretty safe, even overnight. Just kidding. I may be able to find other accomodation, but the essential costs are the airfare and registration fee.

How this will help me

Attending this confernence, as a panellst, will give me the chance to meet and network with other, more established writers, as well as publishers and editors. I have successfully worked on a collaborative project before with 3 other travel writers, a travel series about women travelling solo, which won an award.

(see http://www.worldhum.com/travel-blog/item/world_hum_writers_win_north_american_travel_journalists_awards_12312007/)

I will be looking for other collaborative projects, as well as hoping to get referrals  and possibly even commissions for writing jobs. Speaking to a live audience will be great personal development for me as well, giving me the confidence to speak to an audience of readers and gain a wider audience for my work. The exposure will be fantastic for my writing career, and may even lead to more invitations to other writer events and festivals. Fingers crossed.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, please share this campaign with your friends and social media networks.

story:
New Rivers Press is a small literary press that shares the work of emerging authors with the world and gives students hands-on experience they can use in their careers. Paper Camera: A Half Century with New Rivers Press is an anthology that contains a history of what this press has done. Individual essays from interns, authors, editors, board members, and even the late founder Bill Truesdale himself, reveal the story of New Rivers Press. Contributors include Charles Baxter, Deborah Keenan, David Haynes, Mark Vinz, Alan Davis, Thom Tammaro, Minnesota's Poet Laureate Joyce Sutphen, and many more.

      
New Rivers Press provides the world with quality literature and the opportunity for students to learn about the business of publishing. We need YOUR help to achieve our goals. New Rivers Press is a non-profit teaching press, which means that we rely on donations to keep our doors open. The donations that NRP receives are used to continue turning worthy manuscripts, like Paper Camera, into books that everyone can enjoy and learn from. With the publication of Paper Camera, New Rivers Press will be able to share its message, experience, and lasting legacy with a wide audience. New Rivers Press is publishing Paper Camera in addition to the six new prose and poetry titles that we publish every year, which means that in order for Paper Camera to become a realized dream, we need YOUR help and donations. Please assist New Rivers Press as we continue to share meaningful literature with readers from all over the globe.


Your donation will be used to fund all aspects of the publication and marketing of Paper Camera. Paper Camera is unique in that it is the first of its kind, a book that uses many different voices to comprehensively cover all aspects of working with and running an independent, non-profit teaching press. All of the sections have been written, the editing and design processes are under way, and all that is left is to publish and promote Paper Camera, for which we need your help. 


With your tax-deductible donation to our project, you will gain the satisfaction of helping a small literary press continue to have a presence in the modern world of mass production. Your donation options also entitle you to select from several perks, including bookmarks, book bags, or even your name mentioned in Paper Camera. Pictures of the prizes may be seen on our Paper Camera Facebook page, https://www.facebook.com/papercameranrp.


Donations beyond our goal will be put toward the continued publication of literary prose and poetry by new, emerging, and established writers. 

Our Paper Camera Button prize--New Rivers Press' first logo image, a printer's devil (the culprit that causes mistakes to make it past the editor's keen eye; also the name given to a printer's apprentice).


Set of three bookmarks, specially designed by our Intro to Publishing students for the Paper Camera Campaign. 


Printer's Devil mousepad. Yes, he's strange looking, but he's part of our history, and the printer's devil is part of publishing's history.


This prize may be our most useful. Sturdy cloth bag (it's even washable) for toting all of your New Rivers Press books.


The Talking of Hands, the hardcover anniversary edition, is a prize that keeps getting better year after year. Published first to celebrate New Rivers Press' 30th birthday, it's chock full of authors who are now established poets & novelists & short story writers.


This broadside was created especially as companion to the The Talking of Hands books. We're getting down to the last of the copies.


The beauty of this high rez poster is hard to describe adequately. Printed in limited quantity (only 20!) on 20" by 30" paper in full 12-color imagery, this Exhibition poster is a collector's keepsake. There are only 9 left as we begin this campaign.





Proposed cover for Paper Camera--still a work in progress . . .

story:
About the Workshop

My first poetry collection is almost done, but with teaching and editing it's often the last thing on my list. You can help me finish my book and prepare it for publication.

I want to attend a weekend poetry workshop in Truchas, New Mexico. Tupelo Press's Truchas Perfect Ten workshop is an intensive weekend workshop designed to help poets expand or polish a manuscript of poetry. I will be one of 12 participants in small group sessions run by professional poets, including one of my favorite writers, Mark Doty. In addition, I will meet with Tupelo Press's founding editor, Jeffrey Levine, for an in-person manuscript consultation.

About Me

I am a full-time teacher of English as a second language and creative writing. In March 2013, I graduated from Seattle Pacific University's MFA program in creative writing. A few months later, in response to the ongoing devastation of honeybee colonies and pollinator health due to unregulated insecticide use, I developed and launched a literary anthology called Winged: New Writing on Bees. The book will be released at the end of October and includes writing from celebrated and up-and-coming writers from all over the country.

My work has been published in a wide variety of magazines and literary journals, and this year I was nominated for a Pushcart Prize. You can read sample poems and view my publication history here.

What I Need & What You Get

I need time to write, a creative jumpstart, and some key professional advice. Tupelo Press's Perfect Ten workshop gives me all three. Now I just need a little boost to help me get there.

Here's my total budget for the trip:

  • $1, 050: Cost of attendance at Perfect Ten
  • $400: Cost of manuscript consultation with Jeffrey Levine
  • $165.38: Cost of car rental with AAA discount
  • $360.20: Cost of round-trip airfare (PDX-ABQ)
  • $100: Gas, food, and miscellaneous
  • $100 Perks: printing and shipping expenses
  • $90 to offset Indiegogo's cut

Here's what you get:

Poems! When you sponsor me to write poems, you receive poems in return. It's kind of like Community Supported Agriculture: share in the risks of growing good writing, and I will share the harvest with you.

Choose your level of support from the list on the right, and check out the perks you'll receive in return.

    The Impact

    There are three reasons you should sponsor this project.

    1. These poems are for you. I want to create a collection you'll keep on your bookshelf, with poems you can turn to again and again for inspiration and connection. When I first began writing poems at age seven, they were mostly for myself. It took many years before I was willing to share them with others, and many more years before I understood that the best part about writing is connecting with others through work that is truthful and alive.
    2. Writing changes lives. That's why I teach creative writing and have volunteered for several years as a writing facilitator with Write Around Portland. Writing alongside high school students, the elderly, and youth in foster care, I have witnessed transformative changes in people when they are given the time and space to write. Now I am asking for time and space for my own writing.
    3. My goal is specific and achievable, and I've proven that project-oriented writing works for me. In April 2013, I wrote 30 poems in 30 days as a fundraiser for Tupelo Press. With the generous support of family and friends, I not only exceeded my fundraising goals, but I also wrote a lot of poems! Sponsors received a handmade chapbook of all 30 poems from the project. I'm hopeful that this experience will be even more fruitful, and that I'll be sharing my published book with you in 2015.

      Risks & Challenges

      I've been working on this book for three years now, but I'm prepared for constructive feedback that may mean writing new poems, weeding out certain pieces, and overhauling others. All of this takes time-- potentially more than one weekend of writing.

      I'm ambitious, hardworking, and disciplined. I'll use the focused time of this retreat to generate new work and revise unfinished poems. I'll use the professional feedback I receive to prioritize my work going forward, and set weekly, monthly, and quarterly goals to keep myself on track. During the 30 days of this campaign, I'll log my writing time on my blog to stay accountable and motivated.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      There are lots of worthy causes out there. It's okay if you can't donate! Here are some other ways to help:

      • Share this campaign with five people via email 
      • Use the Indiegogo share tools to post to your social network
      • Send me an email of encouragement
      • Subscribe to my blog to follow my progress and see what happens with my book!

      Thank you!

Send me an email of encouragement
Subscribe to my blog to follow my progress and see what happens with my book! 
 Thank you!

story:
Summary

VIDEOS AND IMAGES OF THE BOOK ARE IN THE GALLERY

This is a project being launched by the Sydney-based Designer of Eidolon: Angelus Morningstar. His works and style have been heavily influenced by a number of modern authors, who approach narratives in unique and complex ways, which have then been moulded by his studies in international relations, politics, diplomacy, jurisprudence, and sociology.

The Book

This campaign aims to help launch and distribute the upcoming book “Eidolon: The Electrodyne Opera”; an artistic masterpiece that is the result of more than four years of research and writing.

As a work of art, the object of this venture is not profit, but opening a rich setting to the world in hopes of inspiring others; aiming to provide a rich tapestry against which other authors, artists, and designers can create for themselves. In bringing out this setting, it is hoped to make a statement about the viability of story over systems, of the value of art as a venture for its own enjoyment.

Eidolon is predicated on the idea that narrative itself is a causal principle similar to natural laws; from this emerges an alternative history  where fact and fiction converge, providing a near-contemporary era analogous to Europe in the 1900s. 

Content: Over 180,000 words all dedicated to setting, society, technology, people, and metaphysics.

Artwork: Over 200 distinct illustrations

Size: 400 coloured pages

Map: Full-coloured glossy poster

INTRODUCTION BOOKLET OF EIDOLON

VIDEO PREVIEW OF THE BOOK

A supplementary booklet, which will contain the official ruleset for Eidolon, will be printed off with this run; it will be available for free as a pdf download, but this is your opportunity to get it printed with a glossy format.

It is important to note that it is intentional for the rules to be published separately; this allows more setting content in the core book, and explored in greater detail. Further, the setting should be independent of any system, as not all systems appeal equally. 

Funding

I'm printing this book no matter the end funding level; so regardless of what perks you choose, it will be honoured.

The base funding for this goal is modest; being the commissioning of a print-run of hard-copy books.

All profits raised from the sale of these books are being re-invested into the setting; to explore Eidolon in mediums beyond the core book in ways designed to complement it:

  • A uniquely designed tarot deck, using the elaborate illustrations of Krista Brennan, and drawing upon the complex mythology of Eidolon. These cards can be used as a deluxe mechanism for telling stories in the setting.
  • The composition of an opera throughout 2013, by eminent composer Cameron Lam, one episode being released each month.
  • The creation of a board game, with pieces and board that can be used as props for the setting.

Stretch Goals

As mentioned above, the main ambition over the next year is to compose a official sound track for Eidolon, with twelve songs, using Cameron Lam's talent, and real chamber music sound. The following stretch goals will help fund that project over the next year. The intention would be to produce 12 original pieces of music, one for each month of the year, to be released each month.

The composition would follow two dramatic arcs, a romantic arc across the seasons of spring and summer, and a tragic arc across the seasons of autumn and winter; these arcs tie in heavily to the themes and movements within the setting.

Funding target $7,000 Overture: Cameron Lam will compose and record an overture (one piece).

Funding target $10,000 Season: Cameron Lam will compose and record a season of the music for the setting (three pieces).

Funding target $13,000 Arc: Cameron Lam will compose and record a season of the music for the setting (six pieces). If this target is reached, everyone who has donated $25 or more will receive a free copy of the music as mp3s.

Funding target $20,000 Opera: Cameron Lam will compose and record a season of the music for the setting (all twelve pieces). If this target is reached, everyone who has donated $15 or more will receive a free copy of the music as mp3s.

Signal Boost

I am also a reviewer for ipadboardgames.org and frequently review game-related funders. If you have a game-related funder and become on of my funders, I'll refer to your project the next Friday.

Ipadboardgames.org receives over 20K unique visitors a month.

Schedule

The soft-copy is scheduled to be completed for December 13th; if you purchase a copy of the pdf with any of the perks, it will be provided to you as soon as it's ready.

The hard copy print run (for maps, books, and slip cases), is intended to be completed by the end of January.

Shipping

Production is taking place in Australia, with shipping being sent boxed via post; shipping costs are currently being negotiated and this will be updated with comprehensive details as soon as they are finalised. As this funder is successful, shipping will be included.

Cohort

A list of the credits for all those who are working on the project can be found here:

  • Author & Developer: Angelus Morningstar
  • Editor: Kurtis Wakefield
  • Proof Readers: Christine Page-Hanify
  • Cover Design: Peter Gifford (Universal Head)
  • Graphic Design: Peter Gifford & Herbie Peppard (Bone Daddy Designs)
  • Composer: Cameron Lam (Momentum)
  • Makeup Artist: Colin Wilson (The Creative Stroke)
  • Emblem Design: Brian Luk (Brian Luk) & Herbie Peppard
  • Map Design: Robert Altbauer (Fantasy Maps) & Michael Wenman
  • Illustrators: Chris Parlin (The Art of Chris Parlin), Claire Pacheco (Deviant Art Link), Colin Wilson, Dmitry Burmak (homepage), Epona Schweer (Indie Bits), Forrest Imel (Blogspot), Katharine Hawkins, Jessica van Hulle (Hourglass 1875), Krista Brennan (Woven Lines), Krum (Absurdo Studio), Liga Klavina  (Deviant Art Link), Lino Dreighe (Lino Drieghe Art), Lucas Pandolfelli (blogspot), Mateusz Bielski (Deviant Art Link), Maud Brausser (Deviant Art Link), Nospherato (Deviant Art Link), Rich Longmore (Rich Longmore Art), Roberto Quintero (Deviant Art Link), Socar Myles (Gorblimey), Soturisi (Deviant Art Link), Tom McGrath (Tom McGrath's Art), Tomasz Bełzowski  (Deviant Art Link), & Vadim Voitekhovitch (Deviant Art Link)

Testimonials

Kurtis Wakefield (Editor): 

Someone asked me "what is this Eidolon thing you keep talking about?" I had a lot of trouble coming up with a response. This is what eventually came out:

I am far from certain how to start describing Eidolon. As an editor, we’ve had something of a troubled relationship, which I suppose is fairly common. If writing a book is like having a long bout of illness, then I suppose editing one, particularly one such as this, is not unlike attempting to provide succour to one suffering a degenerative disorder, without the aid of instrument one, and nothing but a piece of mouldy bread and a bowl of leaches on hand.

What I am saying is that I love this project: a sprawling epic, very nearly all-encompassing, occasionally baffling or inspiring by turns. It is one small step away from being a hundred different things – an alternate history of humanity, apart from the fact that it clearly is not in any way such a thing; derivative, yet somehow avoiding such and being simply broadly inspired, integrating elements of very nearly myriad mythoi; an opera waiting to happen, which it just might be; an heroic poem, in the finest tradition of ancient dead dudes; and many other things – and yet it defies description or definition.

What I can tell you is that it is a joyous exploration of the boundless beauty of the English language; occasionally tongue-in-cheek, other times deeply moving, but always, always with layers of meaning to delight the mind and heart. It is storytelling as art and craft both, for the simple magnificence of a tale well told, and for the sake of charting new territory. It is a game for role-playing purists, and unashamedly so, making no apology for being less-than-perfectly accessible, but still seeking to welcome all who would partake.

Seriously: read this book.

Krista Brennan (Illustrator):

As I'm drawing to the end of my current round of illustrations I've had a good look at the work I've produced so far and thought about how much I've enjoyed working on this project. 

There is a great breadth of imagination and vision in this work, so much that the images I've painted form almost instantly in my mind when I read the descriptions. It is an enjoyable world to enter into; the text is detailed without being cumbersome and majestic without pretension. 

More than anything there is an exuberance and joy in all aspects of this work, which is never weighed down by the deep philosophies and powerful themes it aims to explore and celebrate. 

I'm thoroughly looking forward to seeing my copy in print: I'm sure it will be an excellent setting to explore in games as well as a delightful artefact to browse.

Peter Gifford (Cover Design): 

It was a great pleasure and a privilege to design the cover for Eidolon. It's not often you are offered a project that is a true creative collaboration, and with a client whose main concern is quality and artistic integrity. From the moment I met him, it was obvious to me that Angelus is utterly obsessed and in love with this universe, and dedicated to making this work of art - and it is a work of art, not just a book or a game - the best that it can be. That's a rare thing and deserves support and recognition.  

Tim Scriven (Content Reviewer): 

Congrats Angelus on creating a work of aesthetic panache. While I may not agree with every aspect of its style, I think it has bought to the fullest possible point a tendency in contemporary fantasy narrative, and that's why I jumped at the opportunity to help support this project, which (having read it) is at once deeply reflective of the Zeitgeist, while having an undeniable untimeliness and real uniqueness about it. The best way to describe it perhaps is like the discworld series in its frantic borrowings from history, if the discworld series aspired to drama rather than humour. It's European history, through a glass darkly where narrative, not physics, is the fundamental engine of reality. It's an articulation and defence of the idea that roleplaying games are about stories more than dice. If you believe in geninue independent art, and see roleplaying games as being such art, support Eidolon.

Cameron Lam (Composer): 

Happily and entirely biased on this project, but Eidolon for me is the perfect synthesis of world building, story telling, art, music and magic. I’ve been seduced away from the world, but I can’t bring myself to mind.

Robert Altbauer (Map Designer): 

When Angelus asked me to do the map for Eidolon and gave me the first details about the setting, I was immediately fascinated: 'Not a standard flat or globe map, but a disk world? Great!' It became even more interesting when I received the pdf with all the detailed information about the geography/mechanic of this world. It was real fun to bring the details to life and to imagine how such a world would look like. I can only recommend this project - a rich and detailed world with a lot of excellent art!

Kitty Hawkins (Illustrator): 

The first thing that struck me from the beginning about Eidolon was the exquisite and painstaking attention to detail. This project (the work of more than four years) is clearly a labor of love and the richness and intricate nature of this elaborate world is fascinating and intriguing rather than intimidating - as I have found with many roleplay games. The style is poetic and lyrical without being verbose, and the entire work is tied together beautifully in an aesthetic that is dramatic without being pretentious.

Forrest Imel (Illustrator): 

The work I did for Eidolon wasn't just fun to do, but was a unique genre to work with and I feel that the artwork and setting of this game will really attract the players.

Brian Luke (Font and Logo Designer): 

It was a pleasure working with Angelus and being able to contribute to designing a custom logo and font. Eidolon is a story about romance, power, with a twist of neo-Victorian. The detailed illustrations are a treat to look at. For any fans out there who love steampunk and fantasy, I think they would enjoy reading Eidolon.

Socar Myles (Illustrator):

 

The Eidolon project was a pleasure to work on. It combines elements of many of my favourite  things: theatre, opera, science-fiction, and a touch of the whimsical. I thinnk some of the best work I've done has been for this project, simply because there was no shortage of inspiring material to draw upon.

Tom McGrath (Illustrator): 

There are a lot of recommendations in favour of Eidolon, so many in fact that I’d say that all the bases may have been covered already. Being unable to provide anything that someone else hasn’t already said more eloquently - I shall instead offer a summation of the previous testimonials:

It’s rather good.

If I were to state one thing that I really enjoyed about working on this project, it would be the originality and creativity of the world I was tasked to portray. Rarely do you get the chance to work on something genuinely original. 

Lucas Pandolfelli (Illustrator): 

It was a great experience working on Eidolon. I had complete details for the  descriptions of architecture and character I needed to create illustrations, suitable for the mood of this amazing steampunk and fantasy world.

Angelus' concerns of quality and art makes this a unique project, and it will be a pleasure to have this book on my shelf.

Krum (Illustrator): 

Working for Eidolon was a commission as I like them. The author was highly knowledgeable of his universe, and every little detail has its place within it! Designing buildings and places for this world was a great adventure I’d like to experience more of!
story_txt:
Summary
VIDEOS AND IMAGES OF THE BOOK ARE IN THE GALLERY
This is a project being launched by the Sydney-based Designer of Eidolon: Angelus Morningstar. His works and style have been heavily influenced by a number of modern authors, who approach narratives in unique and complex ways, which have then been moulded by his studies in international relations, politics, diplomacy, jurisprudence, and sociology.


The Book

This campaign aims to help launch and distribute the upcoming book “Eidolon: The Electrodyne Opera”; an artistic masterpiece that is the result of more than four years of research and writing.
As a work of art, the object of this venture is not profit, but opening a rich setting to the world in hopes of inspiring others; aiming to provide a rich tapestry against which other authors, artists, and designers can create for themselves. In bringing out this setting, it is hoped to make a statement about the viability of story over systems, of the value of art as a venture for its own enjoyment.
Eidolon is predicated on the idea that narrative itself is a causal principle similar to natural laws; from this emerges an alternative history  where fact and fiction converge, providing a near-contemporary era analogous to Europe in the 1900s. 
Content: Over 180,000 words all dedicated to setting, society, technology, people, and metaphysics.
Artwork: Over 200 distinct illustrations
Size: 400 coloured pages
Map: Full-coloured glossy poster
INTRODUCTION BOOKLET OF EIDOLON
VIDEO PREVIEW OF THE BOOK
A supplementary booklet, which will contain the official ruleset for Eidolon, will be printed off with this run; it will be available for free as a pdf download, but this is your opportunity to get it printed with a glossy format.
It is important to note that it is intentional for the rules to be published separately; this allows more setting content in the core book, and explored in greater detail. Further, the setting should be independent of any system, as not all systems appeal equally. 

Funding

I'm printing this book no matter the end funding level; so regardless of what perks you choose, it will be honoured.
The base funding for this goal is modest; being the commissioning of a print-run of hard-copy books.
All profits raised from the sale of these books are being re-invested into the setting; to explore Eidolon in mediums beyond the core book in ways designed to complement it:

A uniquely designed tarot deck, using the elaborate illustrations of Krista Brennan, and drawing upon the complex mythology of Eidolon. These cards can be used as a deluxe mechanism for telling stories in the setting.
The composition of an opera throughout 2013, by eminent composer Cameron Lam, one episode being released each month.
The creation of a board game, with pieces and board that can be used as props for the setting.

Stretch Goals
As mentioned above, the main ambition over the next year is to compose a official sound track for Eidolon, with twelve songs, using Cameron Lam's talent, and real chamber music sound. The following stretch goals will help fund that project over the next year. The intention would be to produce 12 original pieces of music, one for each month of the year, to be released each month.
The composition would follow two dramatic arcs, a romantic arc across the seasons of spring and summer, and a tragic arc across the seasons of autumn and winter; these arcs tie in heavily to the themes and movements within the setting.
Funding target $7,000 Overture: Cameron Lam will compose and record an overture (one piece).
Funding target $10,000 Season: Cameron Lam will compose and record a season of the music for the setting (three pieces).
Funding target $13,000 Arc: Cameron Lam will compose and record a season of the music for the setting (six pieces). If this target is reached, everyone who has donated $25 or more will receive a free copy of the music as mp3s.
Funding target $20,000 Opera: Cameron Lam will compose and record a season of the music for the setting (all twelve pieces). If this target is reached, everyone who has donated $15 or more will receive a free copy of the music as mp3s.

Signal Boost


I am also a reviewer for ipadboardgames.org and frequently review game-related funders. If you have a game-related funder and become on of my funders, I'll refer to your project the next Friday.
Ipadboardgames.org receives over 20K unique visitors a month.


Schedule

The soft-copy is scheduled to be completed for December 13th; if you purchase a copy of the pdf with any of the perks, it will be provided to you as soon as it's ready.
The hard copy print run (for maps, books, and slip cases), is intended to be completed by the end of January.
Shipping
Production is taking place in Australia, with shipping being sent boxed via post; shipping costs are currently being negotiated and this will be updated with comprehensive details as soon as they are finalised. As this funder is successful, shipping will be included.

Cohort



A list of the credits for all those who are working on the project can be found here:



Author & Developer: Angelus Morningstar

Editor: Kurtis Wakefield

Proof Readers: Christine Page-Hanify

Cover Design: Peter Gifford (Universal Head)

Graphic Design: Peter Gifford & Herbie Peppard (Bone Daddy Designs)

Composer: Cameron Lam (Momentum)

Makeup Artist: Colin Wilson (The Creative Stroke)

Emblem Design: Brian Luk (Brian Luk) & Herbie Peppard

Map Design: Robert Altbauer (Fantasy Maps) & Michael Wenman

Illustrators: Chris Parlin (The Art of Chris Parlin), Claire Pacheco (Deviant Art Link), Colin Wilson, Dmitry Burmak (homepage), Epona Schweer (Indie Bits), Forrest Imel (Blogspot), Katharine Hawkins, Jessica van Hulle (Hourglass 1875), Krista Brennan (Woven Lines), Krum (Absurdo Studio), Liga Klavina  (Deviant Art Link), Lino Dreighe (Lino Drieghe Art), Lucas Pandolfelli (blogspot), Mateusz Bielski (Deviant Art Link), Maud Brausser (Deviant Art Link), Nospherato (Deviant Art Link), Rich Longmore (Rich Longmore Art), Roberto Quintero (Deviant Art Link), Socar Myles (Gorblimey), Soturisi (Deviant Art Link), Tom McGrath (Tom McGrath's Art), Tomasz Bełzowski  (Deviant Art Link), & Vadim Voitekhovitch (Deviant Art Link)


Testimonials

Kurtis Wakefield (Editor): 
Someone asked me "what is this Eidolon thing you keep talking about?" I had a lot of trouble coming up with a response. This is what eventually came out:I am far from certain how to start describing Eidolon. As an editor, we’ve had something of a troubled relationship, which I suppose is fairly common. If writing a book is like having a long bout of illness, then I suppose editing one, particularly one such as this, is not unlike attempting to provide succour to one suffering a degenerative disorder, without the aid of instrument one, and nothing but a piece of mouldy bread and a bowl of leaches on hand.What I am saying is that I love this project: a sprawling epic, very nearly all-encompassing, occasionally baffling or inspiring by turns. It is one small step away from being a hundred different things – an alternate history of humanity, apart from the fact that it clearly is not in any way such a thing; derivative, yet somehow avoiding such and being simply broadly inspired, integrating elements of very nearly myriad mythoi; an opera waiting to happen, which it just might be; an heroic poem, in the finest tradition of ancient dead dudes; and many other things – and yet it defies description or definition.
What I can tell you is that it is a joyous exploration of the boundless beauty of the English language; occasionally tongue-in-cheek, other times deeply moving, but always, always with layers of meaning to delight the mind and heart. It is storytelling as art and craft both, for the simple magnificence of a tale well told, and for the sake of charting new territory. It is a game for role-playing purists, and unashamedly so, making no apology for being less-than-perfectly accessible, but still seeking to welcome all who would partake.
Seriously: read this book.
Krista Brennan (Illustrator):
As I'm drawing to the end of my current round of illustrations I've had a good look at the work I've produced so far and thought about how much I've enjoyed working on this project. 
There is a great breadth of imagination and vision in this work, so much that the images I've painted form almost instantly in my mind when I read the descriptions. It is an enjoyable world to enter into; the text is detailed without being cumbersome and majestic without pretension. 
More than anything there is an exuberance and joy in all aspects of this work, which is never weighed down by the deep philosophies and powerful themes it aims to explore and celebrate. 
I'm thoroughly looking forward to seeing my copy in print: I'm sure it will be an excellent setting to explore in games as well as a delightful artefact to browse.
Peter Gifford (Cover Design): 
It was a great pleasure and a privilege to design the cover for Eidolon. It's not often you are offered a project that is a true creative collaboration, and with a client whose main concern is quality and artistic integrity. From the moment I met him, it was obvious to me that Angelus is utterly obsessed and in love with this universe, and dedicated to making this work of art - and it is a work of art, not just a book or a game - the best that it can be. That's a rare thing and deserves support and recognition.  
Tim Scriven (Content Reviewer): 
Congrats Angelus on creating a work of aesthetic panache. While I may not agree with every aspect of its style, I think it has bought to the fullest possible point a tendency in contemporary fantasy narrative, and that's why I jumped at the opportunity to help support this project, which (having read it) is at once deeply reflective of the Zeitgeist, while having an undeniable untimeliness and real uniqueness about it. The best way to describe it perhaps is like the discworld series in its frantic borrowings from history, if the discworld series aspired to drama rather than humour. It's European history, through a glass darkly where narrative, not physics, is the fundamental engine of reality. It's an articulation and defence of the idea that roleplaying games are about stories more than dice. If you believe in geninue independent art, and see roleplaying games as being such art, support Eidolon.
Cameron Lam (Composer): 
Happily and entirely biased on this project, but Eidolon for me is the perfect synthesis of world building, story telling, art, music and magic. I’ve been seduced away from the world, but I can’t bring myself to mind.

Robert Altbauer (Map Designer): 
When Angelus asked me to do the map for Eidolon and gave me the first details about the setting, I was immediately fascinated: 'Not a standard flat or globe map, but a disk world? Great!' It became even more interesting when I received the pdf with all the detailed information about the geography/mechanic of this world. It was real fun to bring the details to life and to imagine how such a world would look like. I can only recommend this project - a rich and detailed world with a lot of excellent art!
Kitty Hawkins (Illustrator): 
The first thing that struck me from the beginning about Eidolon was the exquisite and painstaking attention to detail. This project (the work of more than four years) is clearly a labor of love and the richness and intricate nature of this elaborate world is fascinating and intriguing rather than intimidating - as I have found with many roleplay games. The style is poetic and lyrical without being verbose, and the entire work is tied together beautifully in an aesthetic that is dramatic without being pretentious.
Forrest Imel (Illustrator): 
The work I did for Eidolon wasn't just fun to do, but was a unique genre to work with and I feel that the artwork and setting of this game will really attract the players.
Brian Luke (Font and Logo Designer): 
It was a pleasure working with Angelus and being able to contribute to designing a custom logo and font. Eidolon is a story about romance, power, with a twist of neo-Victorian. The detailed illustrations are a treat to look at. For any fans out there who love steampunk and fantasy, I think they would enjoy reading Eidolon.
Socar Myles (Illustrator):
 
The Eidolon project was a pleasure to work on. It combines elements of many of my favourite  things: theatre, opera, science-fiction, and a touch of the whimsical. I thinnk some of the best work I've done has been for this project, simply because there was no shortage of inspiring material to draw upon.
Tom McGrath (Illustrator): 

There are a lot of recommendations in favour of Eidolon, so many in fact that I’d say that all the bases may have been covered already. Being unable to provide anything that someone else hasn’t already said more eloquently - I shall instead offer a summation of the previous testimonials:
It’s rather good.
If I were to state one thing that I really enjoyed about working on this project, it would be the originality and creativity of the world I was tasked to portray. Rarely do you get the chance to work on something genuinely original. 
Lucas Pandolfelli (Illustrator): 
It was a great experience working on Eidolon. I had complete details for the  descriptions of architecture and character I needed to create illustrations, suitable for the mood of this amazing steampunk and fantasy world.
Angelus' concerns of quality and art makes this a unique project, and it will be a pleasure to have this book on my shelf.

Working for Eidolon was a commission as I like them. The author was highly knowledgeable of his universe, and every little detail has its place within it! Designing buildings and places for this world was a great adventure I’d like to experience more of!

story:
HELP CODY DONATE HIS WHEELCHAIR TO A LITTLE BUDDY IN COLOMBIA!!

 

We are trying to raise funds to send/take Cody's used wheelchair and a few other supplies to a 5 year old with cerebral palsy in Colombia. Please contribute! For more details read the story below*  <3

 

One day as I was stopping by a friend’s Facebook page to leave a friendly hello I came across a picture of a very special little boy called Rony. His mother, Yali, who had met my friend during one of his travels in Colombia was leaving a desperate message asking for help for her son. Somehow, I, the mother of another very special little boy, Cody, happened to see the picture and read the message.

I contacted Yali myself to find out more about her son. I learned that Rony, just like my son Cody, was diagnosed with cerebral palsy. These two little boys, born in different hemispheres, thousands of miles away reflect an eye opening reality… the colossal disparity of life conditions in our world.

Cody is 8 years old and Rony is 5. Cody and Rony have a lot in common, although they are both school age children, neither of them can speak. Cody and Rony also can’t walk, sit on their bottoms and have difficulty grabbing and holding objects. Both of them have motor problems that make it difficult for them to chew and swallow their food, and sometimes these difficulties make them get seriously sick. They are both really thin. Cody and Rony need to be fed by adults and still wear diapers.

Another thing Cody and Rony have in common are parents that love them and would do anything to help their lives be the best it can be. But the main difference between these two little boys, born with the same diagnosis, is that one of them was born here in the United States and the other was born in Colombia.

Over the 8 years of my son Cody’s life, he has received care and aid from all sorts of professionals that have been amazing. Some of the help came from government programs, and other services from our private health insurance. None of the help has been easy to get, or taken for granted. Over the years I have learned what Cody is guaranteed by law, what different insurance companies cover, and how to jump though all sorts of hoops to get services and equipment that Cody needed. If you have a family member with chronic health needs, especially in your immediate family, you are probably aware that managing medical needs is a complex and almost full time job.

Today, my son Cody has a full support wheelchair, a special chair to take a bath, a feeding seat where he is fed and watches his beloved cartoons and other necessary medical equipment. Cody is in 2nd grade and goes to school every day at a regular school, where he attends special education classes. The school bus with a lift picks him up every day. Cody’s progress is really slow and almost invisible to the outside eye, but the most important thing is that he is given opportunities and best quality of life we can give him.

Rony, all the way in Colombia also lives with his parents. Children like Rony are not entitled to any government help. He is also not entitled to any equipment or physical therapy. Anything that Rony needs must be privately purchased by his parents. Rony is on a total liquid diet and his parents have difficulty purchasing enriched formula because it is expensive and considered a specialty item in the small Andes town where they live. Large items like specialized equipment are things this family rarely comes across and cost much more than they can afford. Rony has a wheelchair, but just a regular one, not a child wheelchair that supports his head since he cannot support it on his own; as a result, Rony rarely leaves the house. He is bathed in a baby bath tub, but this is too small for him at this point and besides being unsafe it causes him to bump and scratch parts of his body that barely fit in the tub. Rony spends most of his days laying down and he is only seated when he is on someone’s lap. His parents prop him up with blankets to elevate him but this is not very comfortable for him and he slides down easily. Rony doesn’t attend school, he has experienced several seizures and the school doesn’t feel they have any medical resources to attend to his health in case he experiences seizures at school. As a Brazilian and fellow South American, I understand firsthand that these hardworking families do they best they can within their knowledge, culture and resources.

The reason I am telling you the story of these two little boys who are so alike, yet reflect how unequal life conditions are in our world is to ask for your help. I have a wheelchair at my house, it was used by Cody for about 5 years of his life and he now has a new one. A wheelchair like this, in United States costs thousands of dollars and it is sitting in my garage.

I am trying to raise funds to either ship or take this wheelchair to Rony, whichever is cheapest. We might be able to send/take other items along with the chair if we raise more money. The idea is to maximize the funds in order to send them as much as possible in the cheapest possible way.**

This donation would simply improve Rony’s and his family’s quality of life. I am also looking for a feeding chair (such as a medium tumble form*) and a bath chair if anyone with special need’s children have one that is no longer being used that could be donated. Pediasure and diapers size 3 and up are also welcome.

I know there are people in need all over world and it is hard to help all of them, but Rony and his family are the ones who crossed my friend Jamie’s path, and in consequence, my path… and are now crossing yours… and I think if we do what is in our reach to help the one person we can… we are doing our part.

 

<3

 

 

 

* go to gallery to read this text in Spanish or Portuguese

* en la galeria puede leyer el texto en espanol

* entre na galeria para ler o texto em portugues

 

** if not enough funds are raised we will regroup to try other avenues. If more than the goal amount is raised we will work in partnership with the family to see which additional items would be beneficial to Rony and can be shipped/taken to Colombia. This is a one time gift. Anything exceeding this contributions will be donated to the American organization United Cerebral Palsy (UCP).

<3
