story:
Short Summary

We are on the verge of a renaissance of our own, one where we embrace creative collaboration to elevate our creations. The Art of Collaboration is where you can hear from the people who are masters of collaboration.

My name is Sydney Welch and I was inspired to write this book after dedicating my senior year of college to researching Leonardo da Vinci and the Italian Renaissance workshop. I became fascinated with the idea of renaissance and how to enter into one’s own. It occurred to me then that what the world needed to embrace collaboration.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover how to utilize collaboration in your own creative practices. In this book, I hope to instill in you the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for collaboration. Ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you embrace collaboration and use it to collectively elevate your creations.

In this book, you'll learn about Collaboration and Collective Creation.

  • You will engage with the background of the Renaissance workshop, my experiences with collaboration, and an in-depth look into how collaboration works. 
  • Creative professionals breakdown the tools necessary for collaboration in Part 2.
  • Finally, you will explore testimonies from successful collaborators and see how their use of collaboration elevated their projects and careers in real and tangible ways. 

You will love this book if you identify as a creator, artist, innovator, entrepreneur, or creative-type. The Art of Collaboration is a non-fiction book that speaks to the aforementioned identities looking at how to embrace collaboration and learn how to implement it into their creative practices. 
 

The Book - The Art of Collaboration

The book is written in 3 Parts....

Part 1 contains the introduction and additional chapters. This part covers the background of the Italian Renaissance workshop tradition, a look at how it has evolved in modern times, a breakdown of collaboration, and my story. 

Part 2 contains chapters that focus on the tools needed to successfully collaborate and examples and stories of what those tools look like in practice. You will dive into tools like emotional intelligence and defining roles in order to effectively collaborate. 

Part 3 contains chapters that highlight real-life testimonies of the power and success that come with collaboration. You will hear from creators, artists, and innovators who used collaboration to start or elevate their careers and creations. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 

The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December, 2020

The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!

The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)

The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication

The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition. My goal is to sell 250 copies during this pre-sale campaign! 



I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
 
  • An Invitation to an exclusive launch party
  • A personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...
     

About the Author


Sydney Welch is a young collaborator who has worked on multiple projects that have inspired her book. She worked on two public art projects that culminated in two murals being painted at the Glenside Train Station in Glenside, PA during her time at Arcadia University. She spent a year of her undergraduate studies traveling abroad where she initially came up with the radical idea of embracing collaboration. Sydney has since earned her Bachelor’s degree in Art History with a minor in Religion. During her senior year, she wrote her thesis on Leonardo da Vinci and the concept of Authorship, which inspired a large part of the book as well.


She believes in the power of collaboration to make things great. All of her greatest achievements have involved collaboration, and she truly believes that two heads are better than one!

When she is not writing, Sydney spends time with her friends and cousins in New Jersey for the summer. In the fall she will teach secondary English in Philadelphia at a Charter School. Sydney is excited to see how this book will influence her teaching and her future endeavors. She has thoroughly enjoyed writing this book and all the amazing conversations that have blossomed since she began it in February. She hopes the conversations will continue and is so grateful for all the support. 
 

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #artofcollaboration and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page
  • Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

Thank you,

Sydney Welch

story:
My campaign

As a first-time author, crowdfunding is the best way to gain interest in this novel and cover the publication costs. I already have a contract with Iguana Books for publication, so the novel will be published.

Crowdfunding allows me to gain a committed number of readers while limiting my own out of pocket expenses. The publishing process includes costs such as editing, cover design, proofreading, book layout, distribution, etc. As a contributor, you'll be the owners of the novel and have a copy before it is officially published in September.

About Beyond What Separates Us

Four strangers from distant parts of the world struggle to survive on a planet torn apart by war, greed and disease. Can they build a better world and ensure humanity’s survival? Can they overcome centuries of hate and mistrust to unite people in the one pursuit that matters? Can they move beyond what separates us?

Beyond What Separates Us is ultimately a story about what human societies may look like if we continue on this path of ecological degradation. It is for readers trying to make sense of all the unparalleled divisions sweeping the globe and those that understand the existential crisis climate change represents. The book is suitable for adults who enjoy dystopian fiction, character-driven plots, and action-oriented narrative. Though this novel can be characterized as dystopian, it also contains significant messages of hope for a better future.

Rewards

With your generous contributions, you'll receive one or more of several rewards, including signed copies, your name on the contributor's list, and delivery of the novel by July, months before the official publication in September!

About Me

Born and raised in Southern Ontario, I spent a year teaching science in Honduras after graduate school. From there, I moved to a small, remote Indigenous community near the Arctic Circle on the Mackenzie River. After that, I moved to Yellowknife, the territorial capital, and began writing this book. Writing Beyond What Separates Us has been a multi-year project written in my spare time, and I was eventually able to complete the manuscript after moving back to Ontario and settling in Toronto. Working in the environmental sector, this novel became an escape for me, where I could reconcile feelings of pessimism regarding the actions of humanity with the idealism embedded in every person who calls themselves an environmentalist.

story:
“The history in this book is the reason why I am where I am today.”
– Fredrik Olsson / Apple employee


“I’m so impressed by how this is written. It feels way more like a story compared to all other ‘retro’ books. This is all so much about the people, and what gives it an extra dimension is the fact I’ve met lots of them at the STNICCC 2015 (demo party).” 
– Maarten Martens


“I knew the quality of the book would be good, but I am shocked by the professional quality of this piece of art! Everything from the interviews and articles to things like paper and print quality.” 
– Tobias Jansson


“Have watched this go from an idea to being realised. Well done, you have created a book worthy of the demoscene that inspired it.” 
– Adam Ransom


“As one of the few U.S. people I knew with an ST, I always felt like I was missing out on the scene in Europe. This book has done an amazing job to put into view the things I could only dream to understand about: what was happening back in those days. This Kickstarter was worth every penny and more.” 
– Nick Haas


“[...] Many sleepless hours trying to pixel something, joyful hours flew past in gaming as Thalion was our Psygnosis. [...] Back then I had no idea why demos, early games and utilities turned out how they did. Or who were the wizkids behind them. Or how on earth they manage the ST to do things no one ever imagined possible when it was launched! Now I’m starting to get the picture and I’m hungry for more. For me this is not just another Kickstarter book I backed. This is an important moment in our beloved Atari ST history. A trip into our underground culture the way it should be told.” 
– Marko Latvanen / Atarimania.com

 

The true story of a digital underground scene, forced to be amazingly creative in coding and art.


We go back in time, when the Atari ST and Amiga were still revolutionary mouse-operating machines and the future of DTP and interactive design has begun to shape nowadays IT professions. 

The Atari ST and the Creative People

The book series exposes the Atari Corporation, surpasses the marketing of Atari Computers and explores the contemporary life of a demo scene, whose creative people were on a rollercoaster ride to the blooming digital entertainment industry.

Volume 1, 1987 – 1990, BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS (on sale) 
Volume 2, 1991 – 1994, BEYOND THE BORDERS (this campaign)
Volume 3, 1994 – …....

Asking the people

What was it like to grow up in the 80s and 90s? How did the scene people manage to do something the industry did not? And why? Which challenges shaped those minds? How did the early digital artists work? The musicians? Which tools did they use? What did they learn? And what are they doing today?
 

More on microzeit.com

Wrapped in a glimmering cover, volume 2 represents the vibrant pixel era after the events of the 1st tome. 


​The official cover design will be unwrapped before delivery in 2018! Even though we are hooked on this flashing pixelated envelope, it remains a simple visualization and symbolizes our vision of the forthcoming storyline. We start the work on the cover after the finishing of the book production. Thus we are able to find an essential representation of the bespoken time period. The spine will also fit to the predecessor BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS which gained a lot of positive press recommendations.
 

  


Same quality, new content. Volume 2 will be the seamless addition to Breakin’ The Borders.
 

  • English Hardback Edition 
  • 400–450 pages 
  • Offset printing, 120 raster 
  • High pigment inks 
  • Thread sewn binding 
  • 230 x 170 mm landscape format 
  • Size of a 12" Atari monitor 
  • 135 gr/m² semi-matt illustration paper 
  • Surface sealing (varnished pages)

 

More on microzeit.com

The early 90s. It’s the beginning of the end of a digital era.

It also marks the golden years of underground culture. The demo scene grows steadily and discovers a variety of new techniques to overcome the limits of Atari’s 16/32-bit systems – often with an upcoming profession in mind.

The game industry is changing and Japanese consoles overtake the market by storm. The Manga style infects European artists. IBM PC’s are gaining more attention. Philips CD-ROM promises to be the storage media of the future, while Commodore stays a tough opponent. Atari tries to rescue its market share by introducing the Falcon and the Mega STE, yet striving back to the console market with the first 64-bit console.  

Thalion in Gütersloh experience an internal division and must face their origin. Most European game publishers turn their backs to the ST. Former sceners won’t give up so fast, instead they are even heading to new horizons. Only one last thing has to be given to the test: are the crackers responsible for the overall sales decline? 

BEYOND THE BORDERS goes beyond – in every aspect. This volume not only presents some of the best artistic works on Atari’s 16-bit computers, but also gives the readers a chance to experience the downfall of the home computer industry from an Atari perspective. Volume 2 is a highly compressed tome, packed with unforgettable Atari ST/e demos, unbelievable last-minute-achievements, underground background stories and features.
 

The demoscene burts further into bloom with even more people investing into their digital future. 

The following creative people announced their participation, whether as informer or full interview partner.

The actual participants will be revealed in the finished book:

  • Angelo Bod (Elite) 
  • Alexander de Vries (DBA)
  • Arnaud Carré (Oxygène) 
  • Arnoud Kindermann (Synergy)
  • Bengt Sjölen (SYNC) 
  • Chris Holland (Maggie-Team) 
  • Christophe Balestra (Diamond Design)
  • Claude Agez (Equinox) 
  • David Newman (Torment)
  • Fabrice Odero (Legacy) 
  • Frederic Mutter (Tsunoo Rhilty) 
  • Georges Kessler (ULM)  
  • Gunnar Gaubatz (Delta Force) 
  • Joris de Man (Synergy) 
  • Jurie Horneman (Thalion) 
  • Kay Poprawe (Animal Mine)
  • Kay Tennemann (ACF)
  • Laurent Fargues (Hemoroids) 
  • Manuel Pires (DNT-Crew)
  • Markus Velten (Animal Mine) 
  • Martin Griffith (Electronic Images) 
  • Matthias Böck (STAX) 
  • Michael Opel (STAX) 
  • Michel Savariradjalou (Dune) 
  • Mickaël Pointier (NeXT) 
  • Nic Alderton (Electronic Images) 
  • Nicolas Carre (Oxygène)
  • Nicolas Simon (Oxygène)
  • Rich Spowart (Maggie-Team/Alive) 
  • Sebastian Gerard (Overlanders) 
  • Sietse Postma (DBA)
  • Sven Bauer (Eclipse) 
  • Tilmann Bubeck (Delta Force)
  • and more ...


I reach out my hands to even more artists of that time. Some have offered me their collaboration already. 

Additionally, the people of volume 1 will assist with their knowledge and experiences again. They refer as contemporary witnesses, but staying in the background: e.g. Marc Rosocha, Erik Simon, Richard Karsmakers, Stefan Kimmlingen, Michael Schüßler, Michael Raasch, Niklas Malmqvist, David and Tim Moss or Jochen Hippel.
 

Ex-crackers speak about their activities and voice their opinion on software piracy in the 90s.

BEYOND integrates the pros and cons of this deeply divisive topic of the ST scene. 

We ask people from:

  • Vectronix 
  • Delight 
  • The Replicants 
  • Medway Boys
  • Bladerunners
  • and more ...

 

The video clip takes over. Techno, house, acid and the new MTV culture mark it’s influences in the design of computer demos.

Fast 3D techniques become the new thing to keep up with. Sequential multi-part presentations entertain with visual storytelling and through clever programming the little Yamaha sounds similar to the SID. While most coders still squeeze out the last bits of the Atari ST/STE series, some already explore the 32-bit abilities of Atari’s Falcon machine.

Shiny multi-page layouts envision the most creative demo works of that time. A beautiful selection of contemporary motion design on paper.

  • The Dark Side of the Spoon 
  • Decade Demos 
  • Ooh Crikey wot a Scorcher 
  • Punish your Machine 
  • Anomaly Demo 
  • O-Demo 
  • Phaleon Demo 
  • Eat my Bollocks 
  • Synergy Megademo 
  • Froggies over the Fence 
  • Grotesque
  • Humeur Vitree
  • and more ...

 

New plans, big challenges. As Thalion gets a call from a German air force officer, their business goes crazy.

Now everything is set up for a new beginning. Marc Rosocha’s Eclipse is heading towards technical outstanding games and took the chance to start an overseas business corporation. A major circle is closing.
 
Get tremendous insights into the production and press reactions for important Thalion and Eclipse games – done in the spirit of the demo scene.

Thalion 

  • Enchanted Land
  • A Prehistoric Tale 
  • Trex Warrior 
  • Ghost Battle
  • No Second Prize 
  • Amberstar 
  • A320 Airbus Europa 
  • Lionheart
  • Ambermoon

Eclipse 

  • Monster Business
  • Stone Age
  • Lethal Xcess (WoD II)

  

Working out features and flashbacks is a great exploration of the whole book series.

BEYOND will be extended by features on art, technique, history or pop culture. At the time I visited the CeBIT and Atari Messe quite often and can also talk about demo parties and the making of a Megademo from my personal experience.

Popular meet-ups of Atari people

  • Atari Messe (Düsseldorf) 
  • 5th 16-bit Computer Show (London) 
  • FEZ a bit (Berlin)
  • Delta Force, International Coding Conference #2 
  • Bushwackers, Transbeauce 2
  • Electra, Mega-Leif Convention
  • Stallion, Fried Bits 1
  • and more ...

 

Not only games evolve from the scene, but also tools.

Expose Software tries their luck. To keep up with the fast-paced developments in the 90s a lot of new disc magazines appear – competitors to ST NEWS. We ask the editors of DBA and Maggie how they produced their content and what they challenged these days.  

Tilmann Bubeck talks about his work on NEOchrome Master. Gunnar Gaubatz and Joris de Man shed a light on their extraordinary sound development.

What were the choices, what the experiences? Learn more about contemporary disc magazines, chipsound editors and pixel painters. Find an overview of the most important creation tools. We ask the makers! 
 

In the same pace the industry production for the Atari ST goes down, the scene productions goes up.

Artists like NiKo and Spaz use intense diffusion techniques which literally let the pixels flow into each other. Due to the 120 raster we use for print, we have double as high density as offset print normally offers. 

Rediscover the fascination of pixel art on paper in perfect detail.   

BEYOND presents a lavish art gallery with mini portraits of the artists. See and believe what those guys were capable of, with just 16 colors and 320 x 200 pixels at hand.
 

The demoscene plays an important role in my creative life.

In 1991 I joined STAX to intensify my efforts in pixel graphic and animation. I was hungry for working with other creative people. We made fantastic plans. With Matt and Mike everything turned out to be bigger than expected. But there was only one way to go – out of our little worlds. In BEYOND I want to share this life changing experience with you. 

Volume 2 introduces the story of STAX. For that I’ll interview my old companions, after meeting them for the first time in 18 years.

 


 

We decide to concentrate on the quality of the book production, thus the goodie pack is smaller this time. Nevertheless we thought about something new and got hooked up on something pretty cool. No, it’s not the bookmark ...

Get a 5-pack of magnetic buttons! These buttons can be attached to any magnetic surface, like your laptop or refrigerator. The motives are covered by a shiny, glassy surface. Motives by NiKo (Nicolas Carre), Spaz (David Moss), Synergy and the Atari TOS interface. Five different motives in this goodie pack.

Put them on your refrigerator or blackboard and have fun with it. It also was a lot of fun to design them, so if there is a further demand we’ll come up with more cool sets in future ...  

 

You can extend your goodie pack by reaching two more goals! Every 5K we add two more magnet buttons with the following motifs. If we reach 40k your bag will contain a maximum of 9 magnets ...

The Collectors book-set consists of volume 1 + 2. An opportunity to get both volumes on a reduced price point. Further more you get one book immediately. We ship BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS right after the end of this campaign, to any country worldwide.

Get together: vol. 1 + 2 with a special Kickstarter discount of 12,5%. The final cover design of BEYOND will tie up perfectly to the 1st tome, for the right collectors feel in your bookshelf!

The 2nd collectors set contains the demoscene XXL poster bundled with volume 2. Under the label of The Undead Factory, graphic designer Gregory Le Roux gathered 610 famous logo designs from over 30 years of demo scene production and finally came up with this amazing poster format ... 

Why not? Put the demoscene into the right perspective and use your favorite frame. The 16:9 XXL poster format (154 x 85 cm) offers more than 600 original pixel logos in detail. Discover and understand the unions and corporations through fine connecting lines.


 


Based on our experience on worldwide shipment, you find the costs and estimated shipping times here. For Canada and U.S. we only offer priority shipment, to reduce the unusual long shipping times. This does not work for the bundles: due to the mixture of the content, they have to be shipped as “International direct mail”. Please use the Kickstarter check-out to go further into detail.

Single book

Germany – DHL parcel, 5 Euros (2–4 days)
EU – Economy shipment, 7 Euros (5–14 days)
World – Priority shipment, 10 Euros (11–24 days)
U.S./Canada – Express shipment, 14 Euros (7–10 days)

Book bundle

Germany – DHL parcel, 5 Euros (2–4 days) 
EU – Priority shipment, 12 Euros (5–14 days) 
World – Priority shipment, 15 Euros (11–24 days)

XXL poster

Germany – Shipping tube, 6 Euros (3–5 days)
EU – Shipping tube, 11 Euros (7–14 days)
World – Shipping tube, 18 Euros (14–30 days)

 


“As I keep reading […] I understand more and more about the early years of Atari ST pioneers! It had to be something to be part of such a great adventure, exploring new digital territories.”   
– Sébastien Larnac / democyclopedia


“It’s not every day a book is made covered by a demo code you wrote almost 30 years ago.” 
– Anders Cedronius


“With actual tears in my eyes, I’ve just finished reading. Thank you for having undertaken the task of documenting the demo scene that so profoundly affected my youth, and my subsequent career to this day. […] I’ve never seen such quality reproductions of how the graphics actually looked on screen.” 
 – Troed Sångberg


“Beautiful quality and the content is going to keep me going for a long while. This is the beST thing for the Atari ST in a long while!!!” 
 – Steve Gregory / Atari Crypt


“Very awesome addition to my library, alongside with books about NES & SNES graphics and games, chiptune, Neo Geo Anthology, Pixel Art from Demoscene, Amiga bible and many other nice books of this kind ... This one is very well done, so pro and good looking.” 
 – Sydney Plumey


“I knew that Thalion was related to The Exceptions at the time, but I did not know that so many people were involved and that is was so much hectic. Now I understand why so much space was reserved to Thalion in the book! I had a lot of fun reading it.” 
 – Romain Piquois


“Ich bin hin und weg. […] versetzt mich mal eben 26 Jahre in meine eigene Vergangenheit. Das Layout, die Geschichten, die Interviews, die Einschübe, die Bilder – das Ding ist mindestens eine Klasse besser als die […]-Reihe.” 
  – Marc Hofstee


“[…] From the quality of the packaging to the format, content and design: generally at awesomeness level. Looking forward to the second tome.” 
– Mickaël Pointier

story_txt:
“The history in this book is the reason why I am where I am today.”– Fredrik Olsson / Apple employee“I’m so impressed by how this is written. It feels way more like a story compared to all other ‘retro’ books. This is all so much about the people, and what gives it an extra dimension is the fact I’ve met lots of them at the STNICCC 2015 (demo party).” – Maarten Martens“I knew the quality of the book would be good, but I am shocked by the professional quality of this piece of art! Everything from the interviews and articles to things like paper and print quality.” – Tobias Jansson“Have watched this go from an idea to being realised. Well done, you have created a book worthy of the demoscene that inspired it.” – Adam Ransom“As one of the few U.S. people I knew with an ST, I always felt like I was missing out on the scene in Europe. This book has done an amazing job to put into view the things I could only dream to understand about: what was happening back in those days. This Kickstarter was worth every penny and more.” – Nick Haas“[...] Many sleepless hours trying to pixel something, joyful hours flew past in gaming as Thalion was our Psygnosis. [...] Back then I had no idea why demos, early games and utilities turned out how they did. Or who were the wizkids behind them. Or how on earth they manage the ST to do things no one ever imagined possible when it was launched! Now I’m starting to get the picture and I’m hungry for more. For me this is not just another Kickstarter book I backed. This is an important moment in our beloved Atari ST history. A trip into our underground culture the way it should be told.” – Marko Latvanen / Atarimania.com The true story of a digital underground scene, forced to be amazingly creative in coding and art.We go back in time, when the Atari ST and Amiga were still revolutionary mouse-operating machines and the future of DTP and interactive design has begun to shape nowadays IT professions. The Atari ST and the Creative PeopleThe book series exposes the Atari Corporation, surpasses the marketing of Atari Computers and explores the contemporary life of a demo scene, whose creative people were on a rollercoaster ride to the blooming digital entertainment industry.Volume 1, 1987 – 1990, BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS (on sale) Volume 2, 1991 – 1994, BEYOND THE BORDERS (this campaign)Volume 3, 1994 – …....Asking the peopleWhat was it like to grow up in the 80s and 90s? How did the scene people manage to do something the industry did not? And why? Which challenges shaped those minds? How did the early digital artists work? The musicians? Which tools did they use? What did they learn? And what are they doing today? More on microzeit.comWrapped in a glimmering cover, volume 2 represents the vibrant pixel era after the events of the 1st tome. ​The official cover design will be unwrapped before delivery in 2018! Even though we are hooked on this flashing pixelated envelope, it remains a simple visualization and symbolizes our vision of the forthcoming storyline. We start the work on the cover after the finishing of the book production. Thus we are able to find an essential representation of the bespoken time period. The spine will also fit to the predecessor BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS which gained a lot of positive press recommendations.   
Same quality, new content. Volume 2 will be the seamless addition to Breakin’ The Borders. 
English Hardback Edition 
400–450 pages 
Offset printing, 120 raster 
High pigment inks 
Thread sewn binding 
230 x 170 mm landscape format 
Size of a 12" Atari monitor 
135 gr/m² semi-matt illustration paper 
Surface sealing (varnished pages)
 More on microzeit.comThe early 90s. It’s the beginning of the end of a digital era.
It also marks the golden years of underground culture. The demo scene grows steadily and discovers a variety of new techniques to overcome the limits of Atari’s 16/32-bit systems – often with an upcoming profession in mind.The game industry is changing and Japanese consoles overtake the market by storm. The Manga style infects European artists. IBM PC’s are gaining more attention. Philips CD-ROM promises to be the storage media of the future, while Commodore stays a tough opponent. Atari tries to rescue its market share by introducing the Falcon and the Mega STE, yet striving back to the console market with the first 64-bit console.  Thalion in Gütersloh experience an internal division and must face their origin. Most European game publishers turn their backs to the ST. Former sceners won’t give up so fast, instead they are even heading to new horizons. Only one last thing has to be given to the test: are the crackers responsible for the overall sales decline? BEYOND THE BORDERS goes beyond – in every aspect. This volume not only presents some of the best artistic works on Atari’s 16-bit computers, but also gives the readers a chance to experience the downfall of the home computer industry from an Atari perspective. Volume 2 is a highly compressed tome, packed with unforgettable Atari ST/e demos, unbelievable last-minute-achievements, underground background stories and features. The demoscene burts further into bloom with even more people investing into their digital future. The following creative people announced their participation, whether as informer or full interview partner.The actual participants will be revealed in the finished book:
